stem: An acceptable anchorage for a fall‑arrest system is typically:

choices.text: A conduit or handrail
An engineered or structural anchorage point
Any pipe overhead
The nearest ladder rung

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use only engineered/structural anchor points rated for fall arrest.

stem: Which condition requires removing a chain sling from service?

choices.text: Manufacturer’s tag present
Links stretched or bent
Paint markings intact
Sling recently cleaned

rationales.CHOICE-2: Deformation or stretch indicates overload—remove the sling from service.

stem: Compared with a basket hitch, a choker hitch of the same sling typically:

choices.text: Has higher capacity
Has lower capacity
Has identical capacity
Cannot be used for lifting

rationales.CHOICE-2: Choker hitches reduce capacity due to bending and friction at the choke.

stem: Before lifting an irregular load, you should locate the center of gravity so that:

choices.text: The hook is below the COG
The hook is directly above or slightly past the COG toward the heavy end
The hook is far to one side
COG position is irrelevant

rationales.CHOICE-2: Suspending above/just past the COG helps the load hang level without tipping.

stem: Which statement about crane hand signals is correct?

choices.text: Only the operator may signal a stop
Anyone may give the universal emergency stop signal
Two hands above head always means 'speed up'
There are no standard hand signals for cranes

rationales.CHOICE-2: The emergency stop is universal and may be given by any person observing danger.

stem: When traveling with a load on a forklift, you should:

choices.text: Carry the load high for visibility
Carry the load low and tilted back
Travel fast to reduce time under load
Turn on ramps with the load elevated

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keep the load low and tilted back for stability and visibility.

stem: Before using a chain fall/lever hoist, you should:

choices.text: Oil the brake surfaces
Check the brake/pawl function with a light test lift
Remove the nameplate to reduce weight
Use a cheater bar on the lever

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verify the brake holds with a small test lift before proceeding.

stem: Before using a full‑body harness, you should:

choices.text: Ignore small cuts in webbing
Check webbing, stitching, and hardware; remove if damaged
Tie knots to shorten lanyards
Use any carabiner from the hardware store

rationales.CHOICE-2: Inspect harness components and remove damaged gear from service.

stem: When climbing a ladder, which practice is correct?

choices.text: Carry tools in your hands
Maintain three points of contact
Lean far to the side to reach
Stand on the top cap for better height

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keep two hands and one foot or two feet and one hand in contact while climbing.

stem: What is the recommended setup angle for a straight ladder?

choices.text: 1:1 (about 45°) against the support
4:1 (about 75°) slope from the base to the support
Lean as steep as possible to save space
Lay it nearly horizontal for stability

rationales.CHOICE-2: The 4:1 rule provides stable footing and proper contact with the support.

stem: When a portable ladder is used for access to a higher level, you should:

choices.text: Stop it flush with the landing edge
Extend above the landing and secure it to prevent movement
Place it on boxes to gain height
Grease the feet so it slides into position

rationales.CHOICE-2: Extend above the landing and tie off/secure to prevent movement.

stem: Around electrical hazards, which ladder choice is safest?

choices.text: Metal ladder
Wet wooden ladder
Fiberglass ladder in good condition
Any ladder will do

rationales.CHOICE-3: Non‑conductive fiberglass ladders reduce shock risk near electricity.

stem: Which statement about crane operations is correct?

choices.text: It is acceptable to ride the hook for short distances
Only supervisors may ride the load
No one may ride the hook or suspended load
Riding is permitted with a harness

rationales.CHOICE-3: Riding hooks or loads is prohibited; use approved man‑lifts instead.

stem: During a lift with a crane or hoist, bystanders should:

choices.text: Walk under the suspended load quickly
Stand close to guide by hand
Stay out of the fall zone and use barriers/tag lines
Ride on the hook for better view

rationales.CHOICE-3: Keep people out of the fall zone; use tag lines to control the load.

stem: If rigging gear’s history or condition is unknown, you should:

choices.text: Use it for a light lift first
Assume it’s fine if it looks clean
Remove it from service and have it inspected
Paint it and put it back

rationales.CHOICE-3: Unknown or suspect gear must be inspected or discarded.

stem: On platforms at height, which protection is appropriate?

choices.text: No guardrails if you’re careful
Guardrails and toeboards as required
Loose ropes instead of rails
Just caution tape

rationales.CHOICE-2: Guardrails/toeboards help prevent falls and falling objects.

stem: Before using a scaffold, a best practice is to:

choices.text: Assume it’s safe if present
Check that it’s tagged/inspected by a competent person
Jump to test deflection
Remove guardrails to work faster

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use only inspected scaffolds with proper tags and guardrails in place.

stem: For a two‑leg sling connection using a shackle, a good practice is:

choices.text: Load on the pin with side loading
Place the bow on the sling side to reduce side‑loading the pin
Use any random orientation
Replace shackles with padlocks

rationales.CHOICE-2: The bow provides more space and reduces side loading on the pin.

stem: Why use a shock‑absorbing lanyard in fall arrest?

choices.text: To increase arrest forces
To reduce forces on the body during a fall
To make the lanyard heavier
To replace anchor points

rationales.CHOICE-2: Energy‑absorbing devices limit peak forces transmitted to the user.

stem: How does sling angle affect tension in a two-leg lift?

choices.text: Smaller angles reduce tension in each leg
Smaller angles increase tension in each leg
Angle has no effect on leg tension
Larger angles always increase tension

rationales.CHOICE-2: As the angle from horizontal decreases, leg tension rises significantly.

stem: How should synthetic web slings be protected on sharp edges?

choices.text: No protection needed
Use padding/edge protectors
Wrap with tape only
Move faster to avoid cuts

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use corner pads/guards to prevent cutting of webbing.

stem: Which statement about stepladders is correct?

choices.text: Standing on the top cap is allowed
Use them closed like a straight ladder
Do not stand on the top or top step unless designed for it
Always lean them against walls

rationales.CHOICE-3: Avoid the top/top step unless the ladder is specifically designed for standing there.

stem: What is the primary purpose of using tag lines on suspended loads?

choices.text: To increase the load weight
To steer and control load swing at a distance
To tie off the crane hook
To measure load temperature

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tag lines let workers control rotation/swing while staying clear.

stem: When the exact weight of a load is unknown, what is the safest approach?

choices.text: Guess the weight by the size of the load
Use rated slings and perform a short, controlled trial lift
Lift quickly to avoid swinging
Ride on the load to watch clearances

rationales.CHOICE-2: A brief trial lift lets you verify balance and capacity while staying within control.
